Lewis Hamilton won the Formula 1 World Championship
In the United States, for the sixth time in his career and the third in a row: in the history of Formula 1 only Michael Schumacher has won more

03 Nov 2019, 22:45

The British Mercedes driver Lewis Hamilton won the Formula 1 World Championship after finishing second in the United States Grand Prix, the third last race of the season. In Texas, Hamilton came behind team mate Valtteri Bottas and ahead of Red Bull Dutchman Max Verstappen. Ferrari won only a fourth place with Charles Leclerc, after Sebastian Vettel's retirement due to a suspension break.

For Hamilton it is the sixth career title and the third consecutive. This is an exceptional result thanks to which he passed the Argentine Juan Manuel Fangio in the ranking of the most winning drivers ever in Formula 1. Only one driver is still ahead of him, the German Michael Schumacher, with one more title. Over the course of the season, Hamilton achieved eleven victories and three second places. He ran all the Grand Prix races from start to finish and his worst result was ninth place in Germany.
The victory of Hamilton and also that of the Mercedes in the constructors' classification were clearer than expected, mainly due to the difficulties of Ferrari, which played a disappointing world championship overall, marked by problems in the first part of the season and then by too many mistakes, both technical and strategic. Vettel and Leclerc have withdrawn altogether on four occasions, they have only won three Grand Prix and they have obtained fifteen positions out of the podium, too little to compete with Mercedes, protagonist instead of another almost impeccable season.
